novice.question: What is the primary goal of software testing?
options: To ensure the software meets requirements

novice.question: What is a 'Bug' in software?
options: A flaw or error that causes unexpected behavior

novice.question: What is manual testing?
options: Testing performed by a human without automation tools

novice.question: What is a 'Test Case'?
options: A set of conditions and steps to verify a specific feature

novice.question: What is the difference between a bug and a defect?
options: A bug is found by testers; a defect is found by users
A bug is in code; a defect is in requirements

novice.question: What is 'Black Box' testing?
options: Testing with full knowledge of the code
Testing without knowing the internal code structure
Testing a computer in the dark

novice.question: What is 'White Box' testing?
options: Testing based on internal code structure and logic

novice.question: What is 'Integration Testing'?
options: Testing how different modules work together

novice.question: What is 'System Testing'?
options: Testing the complete integrated software system

novice.question: What is 'Acceptance Testing'?
options: Testing if the developer likes the code
Testing to see if the system meets business requirements

novice.question: What is a 'Bug Report'?
options: A document detailing a detected flaw

novice.question: What is the 'Priority' of a bug?
options: How quickly the bug needs to be fixed

novice.question: What is the 'Severity' of a bug?
options: The impact the bug has on the system
The length of the bug report
The color of the error message

novice.question: What is 'Smoke Testing'?
options: Testing if the server is on fire
Basic tests to check if the main features work

novice.question: What is 'Regression Testing'?
options: Testing to see if new changes broke old features

novice.question: What is 'Exploratory Testing'?
options: Learning about the app while testing it without pre-defined cases

novice.question: What is a 'Test Plan'?
options: A document outlining the scope, approach, and resources for testing

novice.question: What is 'Boundary Value Analysis'?
options: Testing values at the edges of input ranges

novice.question: What is 'Equivalence Partitioning'?
options: Dividing data into groups that are expected to behave the same

novice.question: What is a 'Use Case'?
options: A description of how a user will use a system to achieve a goal

novice.question: What is 'Functional Testing'?
options: Testing if the code looks good

novice.question: What is 'Non-Functional Testing'?
options: Testing things like performance, usability, and security

novice.question: What is 'Retesting'?
options: Testing a specific bug fix to ensure it's resolved

novice.question: What is 'Alpha Testing'?
options: Testing by the development/QA team before release

novice.question: What is 'Beta Testing'?
options: Testing by real users in a real environment before final release

novice.question: What is 'Verification'?
options: Are we building the right product?
Are we building the product right? (Checking process)

novice.question: What is 'Validation'?
options: Are we building the product right?
Are we building the right product? (Checking final needs)

novice.question: What is a 'Test Scenario'?
options: A high-level description of what to test

novice.question: What is 'Sanity Testing'?
options: Testing if the tester is okay
Quick testing to verify that specific logic/bug fixes work

novice.question: What is 'Monkey Testing'?
options: Testing with random inputs to break the system

novice.question: What is 'Usability Testing'?
options: Testing if the server can be used
Evaluating how easy it is for a user to interact with the app

novice.question: What is 'Performance Testing'?
options: Testing if the code is pretty
Testing the speed, responsiveness, and stability of a system

novice.question: What is 'Load Testing'?
options: Testing under an expected heavy volume of users
Testing the weight of the server

novice.question: What is 'Stress Testing'?
options: Testing the system beyond its normal operational capacity

novice.question: What is a 'Traceability Matrix' (RTM)?
options: A document mapping requirements to test cases

novice.question: What is 'Defect Triage'?
options: A meeting to prioritize and assign defects for fixing

novice.question: What is 'End-to-End' (E2E) testing?
options: Testing the first and last line of code
Testing the complete user flow from start to finish

novice.question: What is a 'Test Environment'?
options: The specific setup of hardware/software where tests are run

novice.question: What is 'Static Testing'?
options: Testing without executing the code (e.g., reviews, walkthroughs)

novice.question: What is 'Dynamic Testing'?
options: Testing by executing the software code

novice.question: What is a 'Test Summary Report'?
options: A document summarizing the results of testing activities

novice.question: What is 'Negative Testing'?
options: Testing with invalid inputs to ensure the system handles errors

novice.question: What is 'Positive Testing'?
options: Testing with valid inputs to ensure functionality works

novice.question: What is 'Compatibility Testing'?
options: Testing if teammates like each other
Checking if the app works on different browsers/devices
Testing if two code files are the same

easy.question: What is the 'Agile' methodology in QA?
options: Testing everything at the very end

easy.question: What is 'Scrum'?
options: An Agile framework for managing complex work

easy.question: What is a 'User Story'?
options: A short description of a feature from the user's perspective

easy.question: What is 'Automation Testing'?
options: Using tools/scripts to execute tests automatically

easy.question: What is 'Selenium'?
options: A popular open-source tool for web automation

easy.question: What is the purpose of 'Page Object Model' (POM)?
options: An architectural pattern to make automation scripts reusable/maintainable

easy.question: What is a 'Locator' in automation?
options: A way to identify an element on a web page (e.g., ID, XPath)

easy.question: What is 'XPath'?
options: A language for navigating through XML/HTML documents

easy.question: What is 'Continuous Integration' (CI)?
options: The practice of frequently merging code changes into a central repository

easy.question: What is 'Defect Life Cycle'?
options: The series of stages a bug goes through from discovery to closure

easy.question: What is 'Severity: Critical'?
options: The bug blocks the entire system or causes data loss

easy.question: What is 'Priority: High'?
options: The bug must be fixed as soon as possible for business reasons
The bug is in the UI

easy.question: What is a 'Test Harness'?
options: A collection of software and test data configured to test a module

easy.question: What is 'Gray Box' testing?
options: A mix of black box and white box testing

easy.question: What is 'Cookie Testing'?
options: Checking if the app correctly stores and retrieves session cookies

easy.question: What is 'API Testing'?
options: Testing the Application Programming Interfaces directly

easy.question: What is 'Postman'?
options: A tool for testing and interacting with APIs

easy.question: What is 'Headless Browser' testing?
options: Running browser tests without a graphical user interface

easy.question: What is 'Cross-Browser Testing'?
options: Ensuring an app works across different browsers (Chrome, Firefox, etc.)

easy.question: What is 'Responsive Web Design' testing?
options: Checking if a site adjusts properly to different screen resolutions

easy.question: What is a 'Branch' in Git?
options: A parallel version of the code repository

easy.question: What is a 'Pull Request' (PR)?
options: A way to propose and review code changes before merging

easy.question: What is 'Test Data'?
options: Input data used to execute test cases

easy.question: What is 'Stub' in testing?
options: A piece of code that simulates the behavior of a component that isn't ready

easy.question: What is 'Driver' in testing?
options: A component that calls the system under test to simulate user behavior

easy.question: What is 'TDD'?
options: Test Driven Development (writing tests before code)

easy.question: What is 'BDD'?
options: Behavior Driven Development (using natural language for tests)

easy.question: What is 'Gherkin'?
options: A domain-specific language for writing BDD scenarios (Given, When, Then)

easy.question: What is 'Cucumber'?
options: A tool for running BDD scenarios in Gherkin

easy.question: What is 'Accessibility' (A11y) testing?
options: Ensuring the app is usable by people with disabilities

easy.question: What is 'Data Driven Testing'?
options: Testing with a lot of data
Running the same test steps with different sets of input data

easy.question: What is 'Error Guessing'?
options: An experience-based technique to predict where bugs might occur

easy.question: What is 'Mutation Testing'?
options: Modifying the code slightly to see if tests catch the change

easy.question: What is 'Spike Testing'?
options: Testing a system's reaction to sudden, massive bursts of load

easy.question: What is 'Soak Testing'?
options: Testing a system under a sustained load for a long period to find memory leaks

easy.question: What is 'Database Testing'?
options: Verifying the integrity and performance of data storage and queries

easy.question: What is 'Security Testing'?
options: Testing if the door is locked
Checking if the app is vulnerable to attacks and data breaches

easy.question: What is 'Vulnerability'?
options: A weakness in the system that can be exploited by an attacker

easy.question: What is 'SQL Injection'?
options: A vulnerability where an attacker executes malicious SQL code

easy.question: What is 'XSS' (Cross-Site Scripting)?
options: A vulnerability where scripts are injected into web pages

easy.question: What is 'Localhost'?
options: The local machine running the code

easy.question: What is 'Cloud' computing?
options: On-demand delivery of IT resources over the internet

easy.question: What is 'Environment' (e.g., Staging)?
options: A specific setup for testing or running code

easy.question: What is 'Unit' in testing?
options: The smallest testable part of an application

easy.question: What is 'Release'?
options: The final finalized version of software distributed to users

intermediate.question: What is 'Docker' used for in QA?
options: Creating consistent and portable test environments

intermediate.question: What is 'Jenkins'?
options: A tool for automating CI/CD pipelines

intermediate.question: What is 'Maven' or 'Gradle'?
options: Build automation and dependency management tools

intermediate.question: What is 'Assertion' in automation?
options: A verification step that checks if actual results match expected results

intermediate.question: What is the difference between 'Assert' and 'Verify'?
options: Assert stops execution on failure; Verify continues

intermediate.question: What is 'Implicit Wait' in Selenium?
options: Polling the DOM for a set time before failing
Waiting for an element to be clickable

intermediate.question: What is 'Explicit Wait'?
options: Waiting for a specific condition for an element before proceeding

intermediate.question: What is 'Flaky Test'?
options: A test that randomly passes or fails without code changes

intermediate.question: What is 'Parallel Execution'?
options: Running multiple tests at the same time to save time

intermediate.question: What is 'Grid' (e.g., Selenium Grid)?
options: A tool for running tests on multiple machines and browsers in parallel

intermediate.question: What is 'API Endpoint'?
options: A specific URL where an API receives requests

intermediate.question: What is 'JWT'?
options: JSON Web Token for secure authentication

intermediate.question: What is 'Database Schema'?
options: The structure and organization of a database

intermediate.question: What is 'Primary Key'?
options: A unique identifier for a row in a table

intermediate.question: What is 'Foreign Key'?
options: A link between two tables in a database

intermediate.question: What is 'JOIN' in SQL?
options: Combining rows from two or more tables

intermediate.question: What is 'Mobile App' testing?
options: Evaluating apps on mobile devices for functionality/usability

intermediate.question: What is 'Emulation' vs 'Simulation'?
options: Emulator mimics hardware/software; Simulator mimics software behavior

intermediate.question: What is 'Appium'?
options: An open-source tool for mobile automation

intermediate.question: What is 'JMeter' or 'Gatling'?
options: Tools for performance and load testing

intermediate.question: What is 'Throughput'?
options: Amount of data or tasks processed in a unit of time

intermediate.question: What is 'Latency'?
options: The time delay before a data transfer begins

intermediate.question: What is 'Chaos Engineering' in QA?
options: Testing system resilience by intentionally introducing failures

intermediate.question: What is 'Terraform'?
options: An IaC tool for managing cloud resources

intermediate.question: What is 'Kubernetes' (K8s)?
options: An orchestration system for managing containers

intermediate.question: What is 'Shift Left' testing?
options: Involving QA early in the development lifecycle

intermediate.question: What is 'Shift Right' testing?
options: Testing and monitoring in production environments

intermediate.question: What is 'Exploratory Testing' with Session-Based Testing?
options: Structured exploratory testing using a defined time session

intermediate.question: What is 'Defect Density'?
options: The number of defects per size of the software module
The speed of a bug fix

intermediate.question: What is 'Cyclomatic Complexity'?
options: A measure of the number of linearly independent paths through code

intermediate.question: What is 'Code Coverage'?
options: A measure of how much of the code is executed by tests

intermediate.question: What is 'Mutation Testing' goal?
options: To assess the quality of the test suite itself

intermediate.question: What is 'CI/CD Pipeline'?
options: Automated flow for code integration and deployment

intermediate.question: What is 'Docker Compose'?
options: A tool for defining and running multi-container applications

intermediate.question: What is 'Environment Drift'?
options: Unexpected changes that cause environments to be inconsistent

intermediate.question: What is 'Data Sovereignty'?
options: Data subject to the laws of the country where it is located

intermediate.question: What is 'Service Virtualization'?
options: Simulating the behavior of dependencies to allow testing in isolation

intermediate.question: What is 'SRE' (Site Reliability Engineering)?
options: Applying software engineering to operations and reliability

intermediate.question: What is 'Error Budget'?
options: The amount of allowable downtime before reliability is prioritized

master.question: What is 'Wait-free' progress?
options: Every thread makes progress in a finite number of steps

master.question: What is 'Byzantine Fault Tolerance'?
options: Resistance to malicious/arbitrary node failures in a network

master.question: What is 'Quorum' in distributed systems?
options: Min number of nodes that must agree for an operation to be valid

master.question: What is 'Consistency Hashing'?
options: Technique used to minimize rehashing in distributed scaling

master.question: What is 'CAP Theorem' tradeoff?
options: Consistency vs Availability tradeoff during partition

master.question: What is 'Eventual Consistency'?
options: System guarantees data will be consistent given time

master.question: What is 'Service Mesh' Control Plane vs Data Plane?
options: Control plane manages config; Data plane handles actual traffic

master.question: What is 'Circuit Breaker' pattern?
options: Stops calls to failing services to prevent cascading failures

master.question: What is 'Backpressure'?
options: Signaling a producer to slow down because the consumer is overwhelmed

master.question: What is 'Zero Trust' architecture?
options: Security model requiring strict identity verification for everyone

master.question: What is 'Infrastructure Drift'?
options: When real infrastructure deviates from the IaC definition

master.question: What is 'GitOps'?
options: Using Git as the single source of truth for infrastructure

master.question: What is 'Chaos Engineering' Disciplined approach?
options: Testing system resilience by introducing failures intentionally

master.question: What is 'HTTP/3' and 'QUIC'?
options: Modern transport protocol for faster performance

master.question: What is 'Resource Prioritization'?
options: Indicating resource importance to the browser

master.question: What is 'Composite Layer' hierarchy?
options: How browsers organize painted elements to reduce redraw

master.question: What is 'Layout Thrashing'?
options: Forcing synchronous layouts by reading/writing to DOM

master.question: What is 'Passive Event Listeners'?
options: Listeners that won't call preventDefault for performance

master.question: What is 'React Fiber'?
options: Re-implementation of React's core algorithm for responsiveness

master.question: What is 'Concurrent Mode'?
options: React features to help apps stay responsive during heavy updates

master.question: What is 'Tiling' in data engines?
options: Sub-dividing large datasets for CPU cache efficiency

master.question: What is 'Z-Order' clustering?
options: Mapping multi-dimensional data into one dimension

master.question: What is 'Monomorphic' optimization?
options: Optimization for code that operates on one shape/hidden class

master.question: What is 'JIT' in engines?
options: Just In Time machine code compilation

master.question: What is 'Bloom Filter' false positive?
options: Incorrectly reporting an item is present

master.question: What is 'Write Amplification'?
options: When one logical write leads to multiple physical writes

master.question: What is 'TCP Slow Start'?
options: Initial limit on data packets affecting latency

master.question: What is 'Data Drift'?
options: Deviation of data from its original distribution over time

master.question: What is 'Predicate Pushdown'?
options: Filtering data rows at storage level before reading memory

master.question: What is 'Data Gravity'?
options: Concept that data attracts apps/services as it grows

master.question: What is 'Object Lock' for compliance?
options: Preventing data deletion for a retention period

master.question: What is 'Shared-Nothing' architecture?
options: System where each node is independent

master.question: What is 'Snapshot Isolation'?
options: Transaction level where a transaction sees a point-in-time state

master.question: What is 'WAL' durability?
options: Recording changes in a log before application for reliability

master.question: What is 'Distributed Trace' span?
options: A representation of a unit of work within a trace

master.question: What is 'Resumability' in data pipelines?
options: Ability to restart a pipeline from point of failure

master.question: What is 'Pivotal Act' definition?
options: A critical technical/strategic move defining project success

master.question: What is 'Shadow DOM' boundary?
options: Encapsulation between component and light DOM

master.question: What is 'Wait-free' progress guarantee?
options: Every thread completes in finite steps

expert.question: What is 'EBPF' for observability?
options: Sandboxed programs in Linux kernel for deep visibility

expert.question: What is 'Memory-Mapped I/O' (mmap)?
options: Mapping file contents to process virtual memory

expert.question: What is 'LSM-tree Write Amplification' factor?
options: Ratio of physical writes to logical writes

expert.question: What is 'Columnar Dictionary Encoding' logic?
options: Replacing repeating values with smaller keys in storage

expert.question: What is 'Bitpacking' in performance?
options: Storing multiple small data values in one machine word

expert.question: What is 'Run-length Encoding' (RLE) efficiency?
options: Compressing repeated values by consecutive count

expert.question: What is 'Latch-free' concurrency?
options: Algorithms using atomic instructions instead of mutexes

expert.question: What is 'CPU Cache Locality' importance?
options: Arranging data to stay in L1/L2/L3 caches

expert.question: What is 'Zero-copy' in high-performance apps?
options: Direct data transfer without CPU copying across memory zones

expert.question: What is 'Page Cache' in OS internals?
options: Kernel-level file data caching in RAM

expert.question: What is 'CRDT' in distributed systems?
options: Data types that merge concurrently without conflict

expert.question: What is 'Byzantine Fault Tolerance' limit?
options: Resistance to faulty/malicious nodes in a system

expert.question: What is 'Direct I/O' bypass?
options: I/O that bypasses the OS page cache for direct management

expert.question: What is 'Kernel Bypass' logic?
options: Bypassing the standard network stack for extreme performance

expert.question: What is 'Tombstone Purging' in DBs?
options: Removing deletion markers during database compaction

expert.question: What is 'Fencing' in cluster management?
options: Isolating failed nodes to prevent data corruption

expert.question: What is 'Split-Brain'?
options: When two nodes in a cluster both claim to be the leader

expert.question: What is 'Logical Clock'?
options: Algorithms for ordering events without synchronized time

expert.question: What is 'Linearizability vs Serializability'?
options: Real-time ordering vs valid execution order of transactions

expert.question: What is 'Read Repair'?
options: Updating stale replicas during a distributed read operation

expert.question: What is 'Hinted Handoff'?
options: Storing updates for a failed node until it returns

expert.question: What is 'Merkle Tree'?
options: A hash tree for efficient state verification

expert.question: What is 'Erasure Coding'?
options: Data protection method using shards and parity

expert.question: What is 'Off-heap Memory'?
options: Direct memory management outside the language's GC

expert.question: What is 'Barrier Execution' in distributed systems?
options: Synchronizing parallel tasks at a checkpoint

expert.question: What is 'LSM compaction lag'?
options: Backlog of files waiting to be merged

expert.question: What is 'SIMD Vectorization'?
options: Parallel hardware instruction for data tasks

expert.question: What is 'Write-Behind Caching'?
options: Updating cache first, then asynchronously updating DB

expert.question: What is 'Phi Accrual Failure Detector'?
options: Probabilistic algorithm for detecting node failures

expert.question: What is 'Event Sourcing'?
options: Persisting state as a sequence of immutable events

expert.question: What is 'Tiling' in data?
options: Sub-dividing large datasets for cache efficiency

expert.question: What is 'B-Tree Fanout' importance?
options: Impacts tree depth and I/O efficiency

expert.question: What is 'Hot-Cold Tiering'?
options: Moving data between fast and slow storage for cost

expert.question: What is 'SIMD JSON parsing'?
options: Using parallel hardware to parse strings faster

expert.question: What is 'Data Drift'?
options: Deviation of data from its original distribution

expert.question: What is 'Predicate Pushdown'?
options: Filtering data at storage level before memory read

expert.question: What is 'Data Gravity'?
options: Concept that data attracts apps as it grows

expert.question: What is 'Object Lock'?
options: Preventing data deletion for a retention period

expert.question: What is 'Shared-Nothing'?
options: System where each node is independent

expert.question: What is 'Two-Phase Commit' bottleneck?
options: Protocol is blocking and can stall on failure

expert.question: What is 'WAL' durability?
options: Guarantees transactions are permanent even on crash

expert.question: What is 'Distributed Trace' span?
options: A representation of a unit of work within a trace

expert.question: What is 'Wait-free' progress?
options: Every thread completes in finite steps

expert.question: What is 'Resumability'?
options: Ability to restart from exact point of failure

expert.question: What is 'Pivotal Act' definition?
options: A critical move defining project success
